dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh my gosh, I just realized something truly terrifying!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh my gosh, I just realized something truly terrifying!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh? What's up? You look like you've seen a ghost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh? What's up? You look like you've seen a ghost.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's, like, project endings! I just, I never actually end them, you know? I just move on!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's, like, project endings! I just, I never actually end them, you know? I just move on!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that’s, um, actually a super common problem, A. A lot of people just sort of drop them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's, um, actually a super common problem, A. A lot of people just sort of drop them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many cases, I see my colleagues and students enthusiastically take on new projects by quickly moving away from their old projects without properly ending them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Is that bad? I mean, like, I just thought the new project starts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Is that bad? I mean, like, I just thought the new project starts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, yeah, it can really drag down your next thing. You kinda leave loose ends, um, and future problems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, yeah, it can really drag down your next thing. You kinda leave loose ends, um, and future problems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, projects that are not completed with strategic considerations and planning in mind may drag down new projects in many different ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So what do you even do? Like, how do you properly close a project?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what do you even do? Like, how do you properly close a project?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, first thing, um, a checklist. Seriously. For all your contractual obligations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, first thing, um, a checklist. Seriously. For all your contractual obligations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing the closeout checklist for your work with an eye to completing all your contractual and project obligations with a very clear deadline will help you to tie up all the loose ends and bypass loopholes and hiccups.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A checklist? Like, what's so special about that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A checklist? Like, what's so special about that?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Think Murphy’s Law, right? Anything that can go wrong will. And, uh, there's this 3-W approach for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Think Murphy's Law, right? Anything that can go wrong will. And, uh, there's this three-W approach for it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Murphys law states, Anything that can go wrong will go wrong! In order to avoid a train of challenges arriving during the last stage of your project, it is important to develop a final checklist. ... The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: The what now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The what now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: What, where, and when. Helps you, like, really nail down what you achieved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What, where, and when. Helps you, like, really nail down what you achieved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The 3-W approach can be very helpful for working on your checklist, as you list the three major W-questions: What [what the most strategically important objectives of the project were and what you achieved to address these], Where [where were the most pressing challenges and if you addressed all of them], and When [when you should achieve your major benchmarks in working on your project and if you realized all your deliverables].

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay. And then everyone needs to know I, like, finished?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay. And then everyone needs to know I, like, finished?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely! All your partners, clients, investors. You don't want an angry customer popping up later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely! All your partners, clients, investors. You don't want an angry customer popping up later.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From the long-term planning perspective, it is imperative that all your partners, clients, stakeholders, investors and supporters know about the successful closure of the project and about your achievements along the way. Nobody wants an angry customer or especially an investor to pop up at the last moment, unaware that you have already closed the project but forgot to inform her/him and thus technically did not complete all requirements.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. Yeah, that makes sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. Yeah, that makes sense.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Poor stakeholder communication is, like, a huge failure point. Eighty-seven percent, actually.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Poor stakeholder communication is, like, a huge failure point. Eighty-seven percent, actually.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So I need a strategy for, like, telling people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So I need a strategy for, like, telling people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yep. And choosing the right tools. Even, like, B2B personalized presentations are still big.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep. And choosing the right tools. Even, like, B2B personalized presentations are still big.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, you should choose your communication strategy and communication tools wisely... Paradoxically, the old traditional ways of B2B personalized presentations or lately even online B2B presentations have not gone out of fashion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And then, I don't know, a big party? To celebrate?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then, I don't know, a big party? To celebrate?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, an evaluation first. But then, yeah, a celebration, for sure. It helps link it to the next thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, an evaluation first. But then, yeah, a celebration, for sure. It helps link it to the next thing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conducting post-project evaluation and linking to life after the project... With your final evaluation, it is important to formally and publicly close your project by celebrating with a grand party or a formal workshop... creating links to life after this project or transitioning to the next ones.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So much more than just, um, ditching it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So much more than just, um, ditching it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A lot more. It’s crucial for, like, future success.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A lot more. It's crucial for, like, future success.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Throughout our lives, we handle many projects and move from one project to another, thus it is important to make a smooth and appropriate transition from one project to the next.
